title: Multi-interaction TTS toward professional recording reproduction
author: Hiroki Kanagawa (NTT, Inc.), Kenichi Fujita (NTT, Inc.), Aya Watanabe, Yusuke Ijima, ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces a multi-step interaction framework for text-to-speech synthesis, which aligns closely with my interests in audio and speech processing, potentially enhancing the capabilities of generative models in synthesizing high-quality speech.
background: Creating high-quality synthetic speech that allows for iterative user feedback and refinement, improving alignment with specific speaking styles.
contribution: This paper introduces a multi-interaction text-to-speech (TTS) synthesis method to solve the issue of style deviation in synthesized speech, achieving more accurate representations of user intentions in synthesis.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous TTS systems have focused on single-step synthesis, which limits the ability to refine and adjust output based on user feedback.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by integrating an iterative feedback mechanism with a unique dataset of interaction examples that replicate real-world voice direction scenarios.

key_innovation: The framework allows users to refine stylistic elements of synthesized speech interactively by providing step-by-step feedback, akin to directing a voice actor.
real_world_impact: This method could lead to significant improvements in applications requiring natural and adaptable speech synthesis, such as virtual assistants, audio books, and therapeutic voice applications.
limitations: The paper mentions challenges with dealing with ambiguous expressions and specific positioning in sentences that could complicate style adjustments.

new_terms.style refiner: **Style refiner** refers to a specific model component designed to adjust the style of synthesized speech according to user directions, enhancing the expressive capability of the TTS system.
